data: Fragmentary monumental Latin inscription from the amphitheatre
four separate blocks each bearing one or more letters, which appear to join up to form part of a monumental text
First reported by Paolo Orsi in 1889, as lying in the garden of the custodian's hut near the amphitheatre, and as coming originally from the amphitheatre
No autopsy, but last reported as in the chiesetta di S. Nicolò, just north of the amphitheatre at the entrance to the archaeological park.
Area archeologica della Neapolis, Orecchio di Dionisio e Teatro Greco
Archaeological park, containing the Greek theatre, altar of Hieron, Roman amphitheatre, and ancient stone quarries.

Accademia nazionale dei Lincei, Istituto nazionale di archeologia e storia dell’arte (Italy), e Reale Accademia d’Italia, «Notizie degli scavi di antichità», Notizie degli Scavi di Antichità, 1876, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1646037
La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano
Giacomo Manganaro, «La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano», Aufstieg und Niedergang der romischen Welt 2.11.1 (1988): 3–89
Epigrafia anfiteatrale dell'occidente romano. III. Regiones Italiae II-V, Sicilia, Sardinia et Corsica
M. Buonocore, Epigrafia anfiteatrale dell’occidente romano. III. Regiones Italiae II-V, Sicilia, Sardinia et Corsica, Epigrafia anfiteatrale dell’occidente romano (Rome: Quasar, 1992)
Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
R.J.A. Wilson, Sicily under the Roman Empire: The Archaeology of a Roman Province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535 (Warminster: Aris and Philips, 1990)
Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia
Giacomo Manganaro, «Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia», Epigraphica 51 (1989): 161–96
I Taccuini. I. Riproduzione anastatica e trascrizione dei Taccuini 1-4

Paolo Orsi, I Taccuini. I. Riproduzione Anastatica e Trascrizione Dei Taccuini 1-4, ed. Gioconda Lamagna and Giuseppina Monterosso, Accademia Nazionale Dei Lincei. Monumenti Antichi. Serie Miscellanea 20 (Rome: Giorgio Bretschneider Editore, 2018)
Betilienus
fragmentary monumental latin inscription from the amphitheatre
area archeologica della neapolis, orecchio di dionisio e teatro greco
ISic000620. Fragmentary monumental Latin inscription from the amphitheatre

1[---] Betilie[nus ---]

1[---]BETILIE[...---]

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Manganaro and photographs

translation

commentary

Orsi in NSA reports the dimensions of all four blocks: (a), reading TIL, is 1.2 x 0.6 x 0.25m; (b) reading E is 0.45 x 0.6 x 0.37; (c) reading IE is 0.48 x 0.6 x 0.31; (d) reading B is 0.85 x 0.6 x 0.2. The inscription blocks were photographed in the 1970s and 1980s seemingly outside the entrance to the small church of S. Nicolo at the entrance to the archaeological park, but they are no longer in that position and have not recently been observed. Buonocore reports autopsy in 1987. The dating of the amphitheatre is much disputed, between the Augustan period and the early third century CE, and since the inscription can only itself be dated on prosopographical or palaeographical grounds, the arguments either for its date, or to use it to date the amphitheatre rapidly become circular. Wilson has argued strongly for an Augustan or earlier first century date. Certainly it is difficult to assert on palaeographical grounds that the inscription must be second or even early third century CE, and a first century date seems at least as possible.
